title: Jeremy Clarkson loves the internet: "Kevin Spacey spat on Jesus and no one batted an eyelid" - Top Gear TV
text: © Amazon Prime Video Don't expect Jeremy Clarkson to be any less controversial now he's done with Top Gear - the broadcaster says he'll be embracing the freedom of the internet on his new motoring series.The 2016 series from Amazon Prime - as yet untitled - will reunite Clarkson with his Top Gear cohorts James May and Richard Hammond.Writing in his Sunday Times column, he insisted that there is "no finger-wagging" now that the trio have moved away from the BBC - and broadcast television entirely."You can say what you want, because out there, in the free world, there's no Ofsted," Clarkson argued. "There's no finger-wagging." © BBC / Ellis O'Brien Referring to a memorable moment in Netflix drama House of Cards, he quipped: "Kevin Spacey spat on Jesus and no one batted an eyelid. Because the internet, let's face it, is also showing a gentleman and a lady making sweet love in extreme detail."Clarkson previously insisted that there would be "no editorial pressure" on his new Amazon series, which will produce 36 episodes across three years.Gear Knobs was an early rumoured title for the show, after the trademark was registered by Clarkson's law firm Olswang in June.Chris Evans has picked his Top Gear co-presenters and filming starts on WednesdayClarkson, Hammond and May's new car show will be a "credible rival" to Top Gear, says James May
